Br. - m. 'the thinking creature(?)', man, mankind RV. VS. AitBr. Tr. (also as opp. to evil spirits RV. i, 130, 8 ; viii, 98, 6 &c - the ibhus are called manor nápta, the sons of man, iii, 60, 3) - the Man par excellence or the representative man and father of the human race (regarded in the RV. as the first to have instituted sacrifices and religious ceremonies, and associated with the ishis Kava and Atri - in the AitBr. described as dividing his possessions among some of his sons to the exclusion of one called Nbh-nedishha, q.v - called Svaraa as author of RV. ix, 101, 10-12 - psava as author of ib. 106, 7-9 - in Naigh. v, 6 he is numbered among the 31 divine beings of the upper sphere, and VS. xi, 66 as father of men even identified with Prajs-pati - but the name Manu is esp. applied to 14 successive mythical progenitors and sovereigns of the earth, described Mn. i, 63 and in later wks. as creating and supporting this world through successive Antaras or long periods of time, manv-antara below - the first is called Svyambhuva as sprung from svayam-bh, the Self-existent, and described in Mn. 12, 34 as a sort of secondary creator, who commenced his work by producing 10 Prajpatis or Maharshis, of whom the first was marci, Light - to this Manu is ascribed the celebrated 'code of Manu', manu-sahit, and two ancient Stra works on Kalpa and Gihya i.e. sacrificial and domestic rites - he is also called Hairayagarbha as son of Hiraya-garbha, and Prcetasa, as son of Pra-cetas - the called Svrocisha, Auttami, Tmasa, Raivata, Ckshusha, cf. the 7th Manu, called vaivasvata, Sun-born, or from his piety, satya-vrata, is regarded as the progenitor of the present race of living beings, and said, like the Noah of the Old Testament, to have been preserved from a great flood by Vishu or Brahm in the form of a fish: he is also variously described as one of the 12 dityas, as the author of RV. viii, 27-31, as the brother of Yama, who as a son of he Sun is also called Vaivasvata, as the founder and first king of Ayodhy, and as father of Il who married Budha, son of the Moon, the two great solar and lunar races being thus nearly related to each other, IW. 344 ; 373 - the 8th Manu or first of the future Manus, accord. to VP. iii, 2, will be Svari - the 9th Daksha-svari - the 12th Rudra-ssvari - the 13th Raucya or Deva-ssvari - the 14th Bhautya or Indra-ssvari) - thought (= manas) TS.
